title: Most police forces are still handling higher crime-related demand

yaml.title: Most police forces are still handling higher crime-related demand
yaml.author: Matt Ashby
categories: Crime and justice chart of the week

markdown.headingText: custom packages not loaded by helpers.R
markdown.markdown:
```{r set knitr options, include=FALSE} knitr::opts_chunk$set(cache = FALSE, include=FALSE) ``` ```{r set chart parameters} chart_details <- list( id = "crime-pressure-force-2022", title = "Most police forces are still handling higher crime-related demand", subtitle = "One way to understand crime-related demands on police forces is to track 'crime pressure', a measure of investigative workload representing the number of crimes reported to a force per officer, weighted according to Office for National Statistics estimates of the relative severity of different crimes. Over the past decade years, this measure has risen in every police force in England and Wales – doubling in many places. Crime pressure is now falling due to higher officer numbers, but in almost all forces it remains higher than in 2010.", source_url = "https://www.ons.gov.uk/peoplepopulationandcommunity/crimeandjustice/datasets/crimeseverityscoreexperimentalstatistics", source_title = "Office for National Statistics, 2021" ) ``` ```{r load packages and helper} library(fable) library(ggrepel) library(ggtext) library(janitor) library(readxl) library(tidyverse) # load this after loading custom packages source(here::here("helpers.R")) ``` ```{r get and tidy data} # get severity score data if (!file.exists(paste0(chart_details$id, "-data.csv.gz"))) { # download data # Source: https://www.ons.gov.uk/peoplepopulationandcommunity/crimeandjustice/datasets/crimeseverityscoreexperimentalstatistics data_file <- tempfile(fileext = ".xls") download.file("https://www.ons.gov.uk/file?uri=/peoplepopulationandcommunity/crimeandjustice/datasets/crimeseverityscoreexperimentalstatistics/current/datatool.xls", destfile = data_file) # load data file_data <- read_excel(data_file, sheet = "Data - reg + pfa", skip = 1) # tidy data tidy_data <- file_data %>% # extract only columns relevant to severity scores, not the adjacent table # of offence rates select(1:23) %>% pivot_longer(c(-`Offence group`, -Code, -Name), names_to = "year", values_to = "severity_score") %>% mutate( # extract the month/year of the end of the data period year_ending = str_trim(str_remove(str_extract(year, "\\n.+?\\.{3}"), "\\.{3}")), # convert this into a date year_ending = parse_date(year_ending, format = "%b '%y"), # convert date to final day of the month rather than the first year_ending = year_ending + days_in_month(year_ending) - days(1) ) %>% # select(-year) %>% clean_names() # save tidy data write_csv(tidy_data, paste0(chart_details$id, "-data.csv.gz")) } else { # load tidy data tidy_data <- read_csv(paste0(chart_details$id, "-data.csv.gz")) } # get population data for local authorities, because population data aren't # published for police force areas if (!file.exists(paste0(chart_details$id, "-pop-data.csv.gz"))) { # download data # Source: https://www.ons.gov.uk/peoplepopulationandcommunity/populationandmigration/populationestimates/datasets/populationestimatesforukenglandandwalesscotlandandnorthernireland pop_data_file <- tempfile(fileext = ".xls") download.file("https://www.ons.gov.uk/file?uri=/peoplepopulationandcommunity/populationandmigration/populationestimates/datasets/populationestimatesforukenglandandwalesscotlandandnorthernireland/mid2020/ukpopestimatesmid2020on2021geography.xls", destfile = pop_data_file) # load data pop_data <- pop_data_file %>% read_excel(sheet = "MYE 5", skip = 7) %>% janitor::clean_names() %>% filter( geography %in% c( "London Borough", "Metropolitan District", "Non-metropolitan District", "Unitary Authority" ) ) %>% select(code, name, starts_with("estimated_population_")) %>% pivot_longer( cols = c(-code, -name), names_to = "year", values_to = "population", names_prefix = "estimated_population_mid_" ) # save tidy data write_csv(pop_data, paste0(chart_details$id, "-pop-data.csv.gz")) } else { # load tidy data pop_data <- read_csv(paste0(chart_details$id, "-pop-data.csv.gz")) } # load police numbers data police_numbers <- here::here("post/police-uplift-2022/police-uplift-2022-data.csv.gz") %>% read_csv() %>% # Filter only those rows that relate to counts in March of a year filter(month(date) == 3) %>% # Merge MPS and City Police because they're combined in the severity scores mutate( force_name = case_when( force_name == "Avon & Somerset" ~ "Avon and Somerset", force_name == "Devon & Cornwall" ~ "Devon and Cornwall", force_name == "London, City of" ~ "Metropolitan Police", TRUE ~ force_name ), year = year(date) ) %>% # Merge rows for each age/sex category count(force_name, year, wt = total_fte, name = "officers") # get LAD to PFA lookup table # Source: https://geoportal.statistics.gov.uk/datasets/ons::local-authority-district-to-community-safety-partnerships-to-police-force-areas-december-2019-lookup-in-england-and-wales/about pfa_lookup <- read_csv("https://opendata.arcgis.com/api/v3/datasets/66df1640526a4528a78736208daf83ed_0/downloads/data?format=csv&spatialRefId=4326&where=1%3D1") %>% clean_names() %>% rename(la_code = lad18cd, pfa_code = pfa18cd, pfa_name = pfa18nm) ``` ```{r prepare data for chart} # get population for police force areas pfa_population <- pop_data %>% left_join(pfa_lookup, by = c("code" = "la_code")) %>% # combine MPS and City Police because they're combined in the severity scores mutate( pfa_code = if_else(pfa_code == "E23000034", "E23000001", pfa_code), pfa_name = if_else(pfa_name == "London, City of", "Metropolitan Police", pfa_name) ) %>% group_by(pfa_code, pfa_name, year) %>% summarise(population = sum(population), .groups = "drop") %>% # remove rows that represent Scottish/NI population, for which pfa18cd is NA remove_missing(na.rm = TRUE) %>% mutate(year = as.numeric(year)) severity <- tidy_data %>% filter( offence_group == "Total recorded crime", # only severity estimates for police force areas str_sub(code, 0, 3) %in% c("E23", "W15"), # exclude City Police, since its severity scores are included in the MPS name != "City of London", # only severity estimates for financial years month(year_ending) == 3 ) %>% select(code, name, year_ending, severity_score) %>% mutate(severity_score = parse_number(severity_score)) severity_total <- severity %>% # create a temporary column containing the year prior to year_ending, for # matching to the appropriate *mid calendar year* population estimates mutate(year_match = year(year_ending - years(1))) %>% left_join(pfa_population, by = c("code" = "pfa_code", "year_match" = "year")) %>% mutate(year_match = year_match + 1) %>% left_join(police_numbers, by = c("name" = "force_name", "year_match" = "year")) %>% select(name, year_ending, severity_score, population, officers) %>% filter(year_ending >= ymd("2010-01-01")) %>% mutate(total_severity = as.numeric(severity_score) * population) %>% select(name, year_ending, total_severity, officers) %>% mutate( name = str_replace_all(name, " and ", " & "), name = str_replace(name, "^North ", "N "), name = str_replace(name, "^South ", "S "), name = str_replace(name, "^West ", "W "), name = str_replace(name, " Yorkshire$", " Yorks"), name = recode(name, "Avon & Somerset" = "Avon & Som", "Bedfordshire" = "Beds", "Cambridgeshire" = "Cambs", "Derbyshire" = "Derbys", "Devon & Cornwall" = "Dvn & Corn", "Gloucestershire" = "Gloucs", "Greater Manchester" = "G Mnchstr", "Hampshire" = "Hants", "Hertfordshire" = "Herts", "Lancashire" = "Lancs", "Leicestershire" = "Leics", "Lincolnshire" = "Lincs", "Metropolitan Police" = "Met Police", "Northamptonshire" = "Northants", "Northumbria" = "Northumb", "Nottinghamshire" = "Notts", "Staffordshire" = "Staffs", "Thames Valley" = "Thames V", "Warwickshire" = "Warwicks", "W Midlands" = "W Mids" ) ) national_severity <- severity_total %>% group_by(year_ending) %>% summarise_if(is.numeric, sum, na.rm = TRUE) %>% mutate(national_severity_per_officer = total_severity / officers) %>% select(year_ending, national_severity_per_officer) # calculate severity index severity_per_officer <- severity_total %>% left_join(national_severity, by = "year_ending") %>% mutate( severity_per_officer = total_severity / officers, severity_index = severity_per_officer / first(national_severity_per_officer), national_severity_index = national_severity_per_officer / first(national_severity_per_officer) ) %>% group_by(name) %>% mutate( # Change in force-level crime pressure for each year change = perc_change( first(severity_per_officer), severity_per_officer, format = FALSE ), # Difference between national and force-level crime pressure diff = perc_change( national_severity_per_officer, severity_per_officer, format = FALSE ) ) %>% ungroup() %>% remove_missing(na.rm = TRUE) # order forces by most-recent severity index forces_in_order <- severity_per_officer %>% filter(year(year_ending) == max(year(year_ending))) %>% arrange(desc(severity_index)) %>% pluck("name") chart_data <- severity_per_officer %>% group_by(name) %>% mutate( # Forces must be put in order before setting labels, since the code to # generate the labels relies on the forces already being in order name = factor(name, levels = forces_in_order), category = factor( case_when( last(diff) > 0.1 ~ "higher", last(diff) < -0.1 ~ "lower", between(last(diff), -0.1, 0.1) ~ "similar", TRUE ~ NA_character_ ), levels = c("higher", "similar", "lower") ), label = case_when( year_ending == last(year_ending) & name == first(forces_in_order) ~ str_glue("2010–21
change:
{scales::percent(change, accuracy = 1, style_positive = 'plus', style_negative = 'minus')}"), year_ending == last(year_ending) & is.numeric(change) ~ str_glue("{scales::percent(change, accuracy = 1, style_positive = 'plus', style_negative = 'minus')}"), TRUE ~ NA_character_ ) ) %>% ungroup() %>% filter(name != "G Mnchstr") ``` ```{r build plot} chart <- ggplot(chart_data) + geom_hline(aes(yintercept = 1), size = 0.25) + ggtext::geom_richtext( aes(x = min(year_ending), y = max(severity_index), label = label), na.rm = TRUE, colour = "grey10", fill = "white", hjust = 0, label.padding = unit(0.15, "lines"), label.size = NA, lineheight = 1, size = elements$label_text_size * 0.9, vjust = 1 ) + geom_ribbon( aes( x = year_ending, ymin = severity_index, ymax = national_severity_index, fill = category ), alpha = 0.5 ) + geom_line( aes(x = year_ending, y = national_severity_index), linetype = "21" ) + geom_line( aes(x = year_ending, y = severity_index, colour = category) ) + scale_x_date(date_breaks = "4 years", date_labels = "%Y") + scale_y_continuous( labels = scales::number_format(accuracy = 0.1, prefix = "x"), expand = expansion(mult = c(0, 0)) ) + scale_colour_manual( values = c( "higher" = ucl_colours_list[["Light Red"]], "lower" = ucl_colours_list[["Bright Green"]], "similar" = ucl_colours_list[["Light Blue"]] ), labels = c( "higher" = ">10% higher ", "lower" = ">10% lower ", "similar" = "similar (+/-10%) " ), guide = guide_legend(title.hjust = 0, title.position = "top"), aesthetics = c("colour", "fill") ) + facet_wrap(vars(name)) + labs( title = chart_details$title, subtitle = format_subtitle(chart_details$subtitle, .width = 120), caption = "data for City of London Police and Greater Manchester Police are not available", x = NULL, y = "crime pressure relative to the 2010 national average", colour = "compared to the national
average (dotted line), 2021
pressure in each force was:", fill = "compared to the national
average (dotted line), 2021
pressure in each force was:" ) + theme_cjcharts() + theme( axis.text = element_text(size = 7), legend.position = c(1, -0.03), legend.justification = c(1, 0), legend.key.width = unit(12, "points"), # legend.title = element_markdown(size = 9), panel.spacing = unit(0.2, "lines"), plot.subtitle = element_textbox_simple(lineheight = 1, margin = margin(t = 6)), strip.text = element_text(size = 8), strip.background = element_blank() ) ``` `r chart_details$subtitle` ```{r display plot, cache=FALSE, echo=FALSE, include=TRUE, warning=FALSE, fig.asp=1} add_logo(chart + labs(title = NULL, subtitle = NULL), chart_details$source_title, chart_details$id) ``` [larger image](../`r chart_details$id`.png) | [annotated R code to produce this chart](https://github.com/mpjashby/lesscrime.info/blob/master/content/post/`r chart_details$id`.Rmd) Data source: [`r chart_details$source_title`](`r chart_details$source_url`) ```{r, echo=FALSE, include=TRUE, cache=FALSE} chart_data %>% group_by(year_ending) %>% summarise(across(c("total_severity", "officers"), sum), .groups = "drop") %>% mutate( name = "England & Wales", severity_per_officer = total_severity / officers ) %>% select(year_ending, name, severity_per_officer) %>% bind_rows(select(chart_data, name, year_ending, severity_per_officer)) %>% mutate(year_ending = year(year_ending)) %>% pivot_wider(names_from = year_ending, values_from = severity_per_officer) %>% left_join( select(filter(chart_data, year_ending == last(year_ending)), name), by = "name" ) %>% group_by(name) %>% mutate( label = perc_change(first(`2010`), last(`2021`)), across(where(is.numeric), ~ scales::number(. / 1000, accuracy = 0.1)), order = as.numeric(`2021`) ) %>% ungroup() %>% arrange(desc(order)) %>% select(-order) %>% rename(`change, 2010–21` = label) %>% gt::gt() %>% gt::tab_header( title = "Crime severity per officer" ) %>% gt::cols_align(align = "right") %>% gt::cols_align(align = "left", columns = name) %>% gt::tab_style( style = list(gt::cell_text(weight = "bold")), locations = gt::cells_body(rows = name == "England & Wales") ) ``` ### Notes The Office for National Statistics (ONS) publishes [estimates of the severity of different types of police-recorded crime](https://www.ons.gov.uk/peoplepopulationandcommunity/crimeandjustice/datasets/crimeseverityscoreexperimentalstatistics), derived from the average sentence imposed in court for each type of offence. In the same dataset, ONS publishes an overall estimate of the severity of crime per capita in each police force area. To convert this to an estimate of crime severity per officer (referred to above as _crime pressure_), severity per capita was multiplied by police force area population[^fn1] and then divided by the [number of full-time equivalent police officers in each force](https://www.gov.uk/government/collections/police-workforce-england-and-wales). Crime pressure is therefore defined as the severity of police-recorded crime per full-time equivalent officer. Estimates of the severity of different crimes are inherently limited, although they are likely to be more informative for some purposes than simply counting crimes (which implicitly assumes all crimes are of equal importance). For a further discussion of this, see [_Comparing methods for measuring crime harm/severity_](/publication/measuring_crime_harm/). [^fn1]: Police force area populations were calculated by aggregating [mid-year population estimates for local authorities](https://www.ons.gov.uk/peoplepopulationandcommunity/populationandmigration/populationestimates/datasets/populationestimatesforukenglandandwalesscotlandandnorthernireland) to police force areas using the ONS open geography portal [local authority to police force lookup table](https://geoportal.statistics.gov.uk/datasets/local-authority-district-to-community-safety-partnerships-to-police-force-areas-december-2018-lookup-in-england-and-wales). ```{r export chart} # save PNG for social media ggsave( filename = paste0(chart_details$id, ".png"), plot = add_logo(chart, chart_details$source_title, chart_details$id), device = "png", width = 600 / 72, height = 600 / 72, units = "in", bg = "white" ) ```

select(-order) %>% rename(`change, 2010–21` = label) %>% gt::gt() %>% gt::tab_header( title = "Crime severity per officer" ) %>% gt::cols_align(align = "right") %>% gt::cols_align(align = "left", columns = name) %>% gt::tab_style( style = list(gt::cell_text(weight = "bold")), locations = gt::cells_body(rows = name == "England & Wales") ) ``` ### Notes The Office for National Statistics (ONS) publishes [estimates of the severity of different types of police-recorded crime](https://www.ons.gov.uk/peoplepopulationandcommunity/crimeandjustice/datasets/crimeseverityscoreexperimentalstatistics), derived from the average sentence imposed in court for each type of offence. In the same dataset, ONS publishes an overall estimate of the severity of crime per capita in each police force area. To convert this to an estimate of crime severity per officer (referred to above as _crime pressure_), severity per capita was multiplied by police force area population[^fn1] and then divided by the [number of full-time equivalent police officers in each force](https://www.gov.uk/government/collections/police-workforce-england-and-wales). Crime pressure is therefore defined as the severity of police-recorded crime per full-time equivalent officer. Estimates of the severity of different crimes are inherently limited, although they are likely to be more informative for some purposes than simply counting crimes (which implicitly assumes all crimes are of equal importance). For a further discussion of this, see [_Comparing methods for measuring crime harm/severity_](/publication/measuring_crime_harm/). [^fn1]: Police force area populations were calculated by aggregating [mid-year population estimates for local authorities](https://www.ons.gov.uk/peoplepopulationandcommunity/populationandmigration/populationestimates/datasets/populationestimatesforukenglandandwalesscotlandandnorthernireland) to police force areas using the ONS open geography portal [local authority to police force lookup table](https://geoportal.statistics.gov.uk/datasets/local-authority-district-to-community-safety-partnerships-to-police-force-areas-december-2018-lookup-in-england-and-wales). ```{r export chart} # save PNG for social media ggsave( filename = paste0(chart_details$id, ".png"), plot = add_logo(chart, chart_details$source_title, chart_details$id), device = "png", width = 600 / 72, height = 600 / 72, units = "in", bg = "white" ) ```
